ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This is a fabulous class that combines movement study with a thorough teaching of the history of dance and the questions that involve the ballet community today.
I learned a lot about the details and history of the NYCB and the ballet industry. I also felt like I gained a lot in as a dancer.
I learned ballet technique, variations, history of ballet, present issues in dance, and how to pick up choreography quickly.

I learned more about ballet, its history, choreographers, and practicing ballet. I grew as a dancer (I am a novice and Daniel was so kind in teaching me) and now have a greater appreciation for the art form.
Knowledge of ballet history and theory as well as practical dance classroom vocabulary and skills.
I learn new ballet vocabulary and a significant amount about the history of the art form.
Learned to interact with NYCB choreography from the principal dancers for each role themselves, including works by Balanchine, Robbins, and more modern pieces.
I learned about famous choreographers, ballet history, and the current professional world of ballet. I also learned famous repertoire and improved my own dance skills every week.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is an incredible course -- Professor Ulbricht is extraordinary and has crafted this class in a way that is extremely accessible to everyone.
The strengths were the versatility of work and the lower workload, which kept us engaged and reading but not to an unbearable extent. Also, the field trip to NY!  I really cannot think of a weakness!
No weaknesses - the course is engaging, insightful, challenging, and fun.
Great course structure that is split between movement, discussion and visiting guest lectures. Would make no changes.
The course is definitely not for beginners, but I think beginners could get a lot out of it.
Best class ever! Daniel is such a kind teacher with incredible corrections at barre and he brings in outstanding guests!
Strengths - amazing instruction and enjoyable assignments. No weaknesses that really stand out to me, it was a very well-organized course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. This is an incredible course, and really the only one of its type at Yale. If you are at all interested in dance or ballet, no matter your previous experience, you should absolutely take this class. Professor Ulbricht is one of the most kind and thoughtful people you will come across on this campus.
absolutely. this class is such an amazing experience.
Yes 100% it was a wonderful course that was the highlight of my week
If you are interested in ballet, definitely! It is lower workload and one of the most rewarding classes I have ever taken at Yale.
I would highly recommend this course to other students. The more previous dance training you have, I think the more you can get out out it.
100% yes. One of the best course I have taken at Yale because it is like no other.
I would recommend this class to any student with a background/interest in ballet.
Yes! It was a very exciting class.

YES!!!!!  Please take this class if you are a dancer or just enjoy moving! No stress, just incredible guests, dancing every class, and such a wonderful atmosphere!

Also we went to nyc to watch Daniel dance in Twyla Tharps In the Upper Room and Nine Sinatra Songs for free, which was incredibly inspiring!

Yes! You learn so much and it is such an incredible opportunity to have Daniel as a professor. The course was once a week and it felt more like I was taking a dance class for myself rather than doing it for a credit.
